Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Measurements of Selected Combustion Emissions in Nepal and Bhutan Integrated with Source Apportionment and Chemical Transport Modeling for South Asia
Award.AbstractNarration:
This effort is focused on better quantifying the emissions of aerosols and trace gases of global significance from combustion sources in Nepal and Bhutan. Very little information currently exists on emissions from sources such as brick kilns, garbage burning, and cooking fires. The broader impacts of this research include the development of a better understanding of the contribution of emissions from South Asia to the global burden of gases and aerosol important for predicting regional air quality and global climate change. This work is part of a larger international effort between the US, Nepal, Bhutan, Germany, and Italy to study atmospheric chemistry in South Asia.

Chemical species to be quantified include: PM2.5 (particles with an aerodynamic diameter less than 2.5 μm), elemental and organic carbon, absorption by black and brown carbon, smoke markers, a suite of particle-phase metals and ions, CO2, CO, CH4, more than 90 diverse non-methane organic gases, SO2, NOx, NH3, HCN, acetonitrile, and many other types of aerosol and trace gases. The measurements will complement ongoing regional monitoring activities by filling a critical need for better source characterization. The results will help to assess the relative importance of South Asian combustion sources in influencing air quality and climate on a local, regional, and global scale.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project overview and goals:

Understanding and mitigating the health and climate impacts of particulate matter (PM) in the atmosphere requires knowledge of its sources. This project focuses on characterizing under-studied yet prevalent combustion emission sources in Nepal, where ambient air quality regularly exceeds guidelines to protect human health. The overall goals of this collaborative project were to: a) measure emission factors for the trace gas and particle species produced by many important combustion sources in Nepal, as a model for South Asia; b) establish ambient monitoring sites in Kathmandu and the Indo Gangetic Plains and use the source chemistry measurements to evaluate the sources of ambient pollution; c) incorporate the new emission factors into an improved regional emissions inventory, use this inventory to drive regional models that predict levels of air pollutants, evaluate these models against measurements in the region, and explore air pollution mitigation strategies; d) train graduate and undergraduate researchers; e) build partnerships for atmospheric chemistry research.

Key findings:

In the Nepal Ambient Monitoring and Source testing Experiment (NAMaSTE), emissions from many widespread and previously poorly characterized combustion sources were evaluated by their emissions of gases and particles, including detailed chemical speciation, optical properties such as light absorption and scattering, and particle size-resolved chemistry. The studied sources included zigzag and clamp-style brick kilns, cooking fires with wood and dung in traditional, chimney stove, and improved stove designs, crop residue burning, a biomass-fueled heating fire, garbage burning, diesel and gasoline generators, diesel pumps, and motorcycles before and after tune-ups. Fuel-based emission factors (the mass of pollutant per kilogram of fuel burned) were determined for each source and have been published in three open-access journal articles.

These emission factors are being integrated into regional emissions monitoring in the region by our project team and others. In the case of brick kilns, the new source data improved the model’s ability to simulate ambient sulfur dioxide levels, yet underpredicted gas and particle phase pollutant levels. Further improvements to emissions inventories are needed and efforts are underway to incorporate emissions data from other widespread combustion sources.  

New knowledge of source emissions was used to evaluate the sources of ambient PM. In the Kathmandu Valley during the pre-monsoon season of 2015 and polluted dry season of 2017-18, PM levels exceeded guidelines to protect human health on every day studied. Major sources of particulate organic carbon were garbage burning (18 ± 5%), biomass burning (17 ± 10%) inclusive of open burning and biomass-fueled cooking stoves, and internal-combustion (gasoline and diesel) engines (18 ± 9%). Notably, our first estimates of garbage burning contributions to ambient PM pollution in South Asia indicate that it plays a significant role in deteriorating air quality in Kathmandu. In the Indo-Gangetic Plain (IGP), biomass burning, cow dung burning, and garbage burning were identified as major PM2.5 sources. These results provide initial insight to the major anthropogenic combustion activities that could be targeted in efforts to mitigate ambient PM pollution.

Intellectual merit:

Our project is improving the atmospheric chemistry community’s understanding of the chemistry and climate impacts of anthropogenic fires in the Earth system by clarifying the role of combustion in air quality in South Asia. Our characterization of under-sampled combustion sources provides new data about emissions from regionally important combustion sources. These data have been used in to evaluate the relative strengths of anthropogenic and natural sources to ambient PM in Nepal, to develop more accurate emission inventories in South Asia, and develop more representative regional air quality models. This work benefits society by informing air pollution mitigation strategies. More broadly, our research products can help to improve the understanding of the health outcomes associated with human exposures to source emissions and ambient air pollution.

Our results have been disseminated to the scientific community through five open-access scientific articles (three published, two in review).  The University of Iowa team has delivered sixteen scientific conference presentations at local, regional, national, and international venues. Additionally, this research has contributed to two doctoral theses in Chemistry (one complete and one in progress) and two undergraduate Honor’s theses in Chemistry at the University of Iowa.

Broader impacts of this research include the training of three graduate students pursuing doctoral degrees in Chemistry at the University of Iowa and five undergraduate students. This research project has supported the career development of the involved researchers, by providing research, training, and mentoring opportunities.  In addition, this project has strengthened collaborations between the PI and the other PIs collaborating on this project across the University of Iowa, University of Montana, University of Virginia, Emory University, and Drexel University, as well as our international partners: the International Center for Integrated Mountain Development (ICIMOD) and Institute for Advanced Sustainability Studies (IASS).
